comments.body: Feel free to add @conda-forge/jupyter-book ! I accept co-maintenance on our behalf, as it helps us keep track of the moving pieces :grimacing:

Indeed. And we'd :heart:  to add you as a co-maintainer on `jupyter-book-feedstock`! It's most straightforward if you make the PR [adding yourself there](https://github.com/conda-forge/jupyter-book-feedstock/blob/master/recipe/meta.yaml#L67), pretty easy to do through the UI :grin:, and then fire off a `@conda-forge-admin please rerender` so it updates the README. No build number bump would be required.

If you _really_ want to run tests (which is cool with me), then, provided the tags are created in a predictable way, one can _also_ download the github tarball (the bot will also update that).


```yaml
source:
- folder: dist
  # whatever's already there
- folder: src
  url: https://github.com/executablebooks/jupyter-book/archive/v{{ version }}.tar.gz
  sha256: <whatever it is>

build:
  scripts: cd dist && # whatever's already there

test:
  source_files:
    - src/tests
  commands:
    - cd src && pytest # whatever

extras:
  license_file: dist/LICENSE
```

Thanks, @bollwyvl for your detailed explanation. But, I think the appropriate thing to do for this PR as per your's and @chrisjsewell's comment, is to do only `pip-check` for now. So, I will just pull everything related to `pytest`.

> And we'd ‚ù§Ô∏è to add you as a co-maintainer on `jupyter-book-feedstock`! It's most straightforward if you make the PR [adding yourself there](https://github.com/conda-forge/jupyter-book-feedstock/blob/master/recipe/meta.yaml#L67), pretty easy to do through the UI üòÅ, and then fire off a `@conda-forge-admin please rerender` so it updates the README. No build number bump would be required.

Have created a PR here https://github.com/conda-forge/jupyter-book-feedstock/pull/3 .  The rerender worked with that comment. pretty dope setup üò¨
